Need to understand why at the first time the index.html page is loaded, if I click on the option that will refer to itself, it recalls the same page while next times I click it won't. Please check the code for further details. I think this is because Framework7 is using the full URL of the page to identify it. So when you first load your app the page it's on is `http://path.to/page/index.html` and when you click your link with `href="index.html"` the new page is just `index.html` with no path. Since the url (`index.html`) doesn't match the original page url (`http://path.to/page/index.html`) it makes a request to the page. Quick test of this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ozgnowj--MA So the easiest fix would be to just replace your index button with a full path link. Seeing all these Apps in iOS 7/8 having different themes (Settings: Blue items, Calendar: Red items, Notes: Yellow items) made me think that Framework7 should also have support for theming Navigation bars, Toolbars, Links etc. My idea is pretty simple: The user is given 3 modes for theming: Global, View and Page. **Global**: The chosen theme is applied throughout the entire website, every View and every Page. **View**: Theming is applied only to the View the user adds the theming class to, and therefore to any Page this View contains. Other Views still have their default (unthemed) appearance, or, if the user decides, any other theming class. **Page**: Theming does affect chosen Pages only and leaves other Pages or Views in their given state. These values can override previous values, which means **View** overrides **Global** and **Page** overrides **View** (including **Global**). Added manual hoisting and single line brackets as debugging aids This was quite a bit of work, it would be a terrible shame if it goes to waste. In most languages it is easier to read and more memory efficient to declare a variable as close to its use as possible, **in JavaScript however this is not the case.** Placing the initial var declaration at the top of a function is actually doing what the parser does any ways. I do agree that in most languages it reduces readability but in javascript declaring your variables at the top is really just replicating what the parser is doing. Manual hoisting increases readability and helps to prevent certain bugs from occurring; it forces you as well as contributors to pay attention to where and when the var has been declared. Consider the following (excerpt from _http://code.tutsplus.com/tutorials/javascript-hoisting-explained--net-15092_) ``` var myvar = 'my value'; (function() { alert(myvar); // undefined var myvar = 'local value'; })(); ``` One would normally assume that the alert will show the global var which was defined prior to the function 'my value' but in fact **it will show undefined** due to how javascript handles its variables. What happens is **javascript hoists the myvar declared within the function to the top of the function at runtime** thus preventing access to the global var of the same name, which is why it alerts as undefined. **This is what javascript is actually doing** ``` var myvar = 'my value'; (function() { var myvar = undefined; alert(myvar); // undefined myvar = 'local value'; })(); ``` In order to prevent the above situation the recommended way to write the above snippet is using the above example showing what happens or as follows: ``` var myvar = 'my value'; (function() { var myvar = 'local value'; alert(myvar); // local value })(); ``` Regarding the brackets on the single line commands, as a minimalist I too like to leave them out. However since **this is going to be the greatest mobile framework ever conceived**, adding them as a matter of habit helps prevent bugs which occur from forgetting to add the semicolon (especially when minimizing) consider the following ``` var a; var b; if (a===true) alert(a); alert(b); ``` looks like this compressed ``` var a, b;if (a===true)alert(a);alert(b); ``` Now imagine someone new to javascript forgets the semicolon the following would behave very differently ``` var a, b;if (a===true)alert(a)alert(b) ``` This particular dynamic popup issue might be a corner case scenario, however here is the scenario which is causing the problem for us.
